history.text: This film has a very interesting plot.
I did not know it was produced by Steve Jobs either.
Yes, the idea of toys coming alive has never really been done before.
Well it was directed by John Lasseter.
And executive-produced by Steve Jobs
I didn't know that either.
Do you think the movie deserved the high praise it got?
Yes, because the plot was unlike anything used before and it has claimed the interest of its viewers since it was made.
Fair enough. It just surprises me that an animated movie would be so acclaimed.
I think it has to do with being the "first feature-length computer-animated film and the first feature film produced by Pixar"
That does sound like it would lend some prestige to the movie.

Firsts are not typically forgotten, but having seen the movie and grown up with it as a kid, I can honestly say that it has stuck with me through my childhood and into adulthood. It is a hard movie to forget for so many people so there has to be more to that I suppose.
That's true. What did you think of Tim Allen as Buzz Lightyear?
This movie also has a very well-developed plot line that keeps its viewers hooked and allows children to resonate with it because most kids have toys similar to the ones in this movie.
I can't imagine anybody else playing him
I agree. Without him, the movie would not be the same
Do you generally watch movies with ratings as high as this one?

Not this high so I guess I am a little sur
prised that this movie got such a high rating.
I think this movie targets children and attempts to correct feelings of jealousy and anger they may have towards their friends and/or siblings
I agree. The rivalry between Woody and Buzz is a major theme.
The fact that they become best friends at the end gives a positive message to all those watching.
Yes I agree.
I think the part where Buzz and Woody get stuck in a crane game is one of the best parts of the movie.
Do you feel this movie has been continuously brought up again and again throughout your life?
I think this scene says a lot about the teamwork theme that continuously uprises throughout the film
Yes, I feel like there is a lot in this movie I can relate to.
Especially as a kid, it would be very beneficial for them to grow up with a movie like this to help them interact with people around them better and with a more positive attitude
Exactly. The friendship that Buzz and Woody form is a positive inspiration.
Do you think it is not a good idea to portray Andy as a kid that continues to get new things and forget about the old things?
I think kids are normally like that, so I see no problem portraying Andy like that.
